Body:
I've read verifying detached signature with BC, but still I don't know how I can verify Mdm-Signature of MDM message from iOS device.

Apple's Mobile Device Management Protocol Reference document said as follows:

If the value of the SignMessage field in the MDM payload is set to true, each message coming from the device will carry an additional HTTP header named Mdm-Signature. This header contains a BASE64-encoded CMS Detached Signature of the message.

So I set the value of the SignMessage field to true. Then the device carried an header named Mdm-Signature. And I used the method provided by the article of the link above, verifySign(byte[] signedData, byte[]bPlainText) like below (I modified return type to boolean. It returns true if verification successed):

boolean verified = verifySign(Base64.decode(request.getHeader('Mdm-Signature')),                   IOUtils.toString(request.getInputStream(), 'utf-8').getBytes());

(The variable 'request' above is the instance of HttpServletRequest class that is passed to doPut method of HttpServlet class.)

But the value of 'verified' is false.

So what I wonder is what paramter exactly I have to pass to the method verifySign().

See also followings:

  • The client includes an “Mdm-Signature:? header in the HTTP PUT messages it sends to the server
  • This signature is a base-64 encoded, .DER format, SMIME signature
  • The content which is signed is not included in the signature, but is instead the content of the PUT itself — the message being sent
    to the MDM server
  • Finally, it’s signed using the private Identity key that was sent to the device at MDM enrollment

These are from this page.What I also wonder from these is whether the server needs client public key to verify detached signature. No need?
Title: Verifying Detached Signature (Mdm-Signature) of iOS MDM messages

Body:
i am trying to learn and understand polymorphism in java. i am reading a textbook where there was an example for Polymorphism with Static Methods

class one{    static void calculate(double x){        System.out.println('square value - '+(x*x));    }}class two extends one{    static void calculate(double x){        System.out.println('square root - '+Math.sqrt(x));    }}public class Rough{    public static void main(String args[]){        //Super class reference refers to sub class object        one o=new two();        //call calculate method using super class reference        o.calculate(25);    }}

i tried to understand why they were doing

one o=new two();

i mean, to use the super class method, wouldn't it be easier to just do

one o=new one();

and to use sub class method,

two t=new two();

Body:
I have stumbled upon a weird phenomenon around which I cannot get my head around so there I am in hope that someone is able and willing to explain what happens there.

Background:

My app uses the FloatingActionButton (FAB) in its main activity. Initially the button has an animation applied to rotate itself. So as soon as the activity loads the button is rotating. When user clicks the button some lengthy work is done on a separate thread. When the work is done the spinning animation of the FAB is cleared so that the button remains still.

Implementation:

I have created a separate activity with minimal code just to demonstrate the case. The rotating animation is applied in activity's onCreate(). The work on a separate thread is done by AsyncTask's doInBackground() method. In this case it simply waits for 4 seconds. Finally the animation is stopped by AsyncTask's onPostExecute() method.

Source:MainActivity.java public class MainActivity extends AppCompatActivity {

    private FloatingActionButton mFab;    @Override    protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);        setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);        mFab = (FloatingActionButton) findViewById(R.id.fab);        mFab.startAnimation(AnimationUtils.loadAnimation(this, R.anim.refresh_fab_refreshing_anim));        mFab.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener() {            @Override            public void onClick(View view) {                new AsyncTask<Void, Void, Void>(){                    @Override                    protected Void doInBackground(Void... voids) {                        try {                            Thread.sleep(4000); // Some heavy work done here.                        } catch (InterruptedException e) {                            e.printStackTrace();                        }                        return null;                    }                    @Override                    protected void onPostExecute(Void aVoid) {                        mFab.clearAnimation();                    }                }.execute();            }        });    }

Problem:

The app behaves as expected in most cases but one. If you click the FAB button and before its onPostExecute() is called change the orientation of the device. Then when the activity is re-created and the onPostExecute() is called the rotation animation will not be stopped by the clearAnimation() method. I have tried to present my question as clearly as I could but if it still seems vague please let me know and I'll try again.

My Attempts

In the original app I have tried all the typical debugging methods, made sure all the methods are actually called and that the references point to where they should. Tried, desperate things like putting clearAnimation() in runOnUiThread() even though it already runs on the UI thread anyway. It may as well be that the problem may lie in the lack of understanding about the Android framework. :) Your help and advice is, as always, greatly appreciated.
Title: Calling clearAnimation() in onPostExecute() of an AsyncTask has no effect if orientation change occurred during doInBackground()

I am attempting to take n number of user input integers and display a histogram corresponding to the number of entries from one to 10. Now I am a complete Java beginner so this may be a stupid question, but when I printed my array (userList) to test if it worked properly, it displayed a random assortment of characters(I@55f96302). I can't seem to figure out why it is not working. It can be found in the addUserNum method. For clarification the reason I have the main class as A03Q3 is because of teacher requirements. I also noticed that I receive an out of index error any time I enter a number other than one or if I enter 1 less than 10 times. I am not sure if that is due to my array being junk or if I need to tweak my for loops in my toString method. see code below. Thank you in advanced for any help!

import java.util.*;public class Miller_A03Q3 {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Histogram histogram = new Histogram();        do{            histogram.addUserNum();        }while(histogram.userIn > 0 && histogram.userIn < 11);            histogram.toString();}   public static class Histogram{    int[] userList = new int[1];    private int count;    int userIn;    // constructor    public Histogram(){        int[] userList = new int[1];        count = 0;    }    // Add number to array    public void addUserNum(){        Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);        System.out.print('Enter a value to plot: ');         userIn = scan.nextInt();        if(count <= userList.length){            increaseSize();                        if(userIn > 0 && userIn < 10){            userList[count] = userIn;            count ++;                        }        }        }    // increase size of array at entry    private void increaseSize(){        int [] temp = new int [userList.length +1];        for(int userNum = 0; userNum < userList.length; userNum ++){            temp[userNum] = userList[userNum];        }            userList = temp;    }    // print the histogram        @Override    public String toString(){            System.out.print(userList);        for( int i = 1; i <= 10; i++){            System.out.print(i + ' | ' + 't');            for(int j = 0;j <= userList.length; j++){                if( userList[i] == i){                    System.out.print('# ');                    System.out.print('');                }            }                        System.out.print('n');        }                return 'done';    }    }}

Body:
I am using Firebase to handle the authentication in a Java web application, with Spring Boot and Thymeleaf. I enabled Google sign in only.

On the front-end I managed to make Firebase work correctly and authenticate the user. So the front-end is fine.

When it comes to validating the token in the back-end, I am trying to use Firebase Admin SDK as recommended in the documentation.

https://firebase.google.com/docs/admin/setup

I am using the latest version to date.

compile('com.google.firebase:firebase-admin:4.1.1')

I am initialising Firebase in the back-end, to then verify the Google token I got in the front-end using Javascript, and that I am passing to the back-end in a POST request.

https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/admin/verify-id-tokens

The problem is that Firebase doesn't seem to load the credentials from the credentials file that you have to download for you application (how to get the credentials file is documented in the first link above, and it is just a JSON file with things like type, project_id, private_key and so on).

try (FileInputStream serviceAccount = new FileInputStream(credentialsFilePath)) {    FirebaseOptions options = new FirebaseOptions.Builder()      .setCredential(FirebaseCredentials.fromCertificate(serviceAccount))      .setDatabaseUrl(databaseURL)      .build();    FirebaseApp.initializeApp(options);} catch (IOException e) {    LOG.error('Firebase credentials file not found');    throw e;}

It is definitely finding the file, but when I inspect the credentials they have null values, and when I try to verify the token I get this exception.

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: projectId must be setat com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:122)at com.google.firebase.auth.internal.FirebaseTokenVerifier.<init>(FirebaseTokenVerifier.java:50)at com.google.firebase.auth.internal.FirebaseTokenVerifier$Builder.build(FirebaseTokenVerifier.java:212)at com.google.firebase.auth.FirebaseAuth$2.then(FirebaseAuth.java:156)at com.google.firebase.auth.FirebaseAuth$2.then(FirebaseAuth.java:152)at com.google.firebase.tasks.ContinueWithCompletionListener$1.run(ContinueWithCompletionListener.java:33)at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1142)at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:617)at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)

I have read through the documentation and looked at the examples in their GitHub repository but they don't seem to have a full working example of Firebase using Java in a web application.

So the question is, how can I make it work? how is people using Firebase in this context?

Thanks.

P.S. 1: I am not running the application in Google Cloud Platform, so I cannot use FirebaseCredentials.applicationDefault() to let Google automatically load the credentials.

P.S. 2: I had to exclude module: 'guava-jdk5' from the Firebase dependency because I am also using spring-data-elasticsearch and it was not working because of a dependency clash. But I still have guava:18.0 in the classpath.
Title: Firebase not loading credentials in Java

Body:
please help to overcome the following problem.When I call stored procedure which was recently recompiled I'm getting an error ORA - 'ORA-04068: Existing state of packages has been discarded.' I know that when connection is closed in code it is just returned to the pool but still exists in the session. I know that that one of the possible solution is to catch this error and call procedure again in catch block, somehow like this:

    callProcedure(Params params){         SimpleJdbcCall jdbcCall = getSimpleJdbcCall();            Map<String, Object> results = Collections.EMPTY_MAP;            try {                results = jdbcCall.execute(params);            }catch (UncategorizedSQLException ex){                if (checkOra04067Exception(ex)){                    callProcedure(params);                }            }            return results;        }        private boolean checkOra04067Exception(UncategorizedSQLException ex){            return '72000'.equals(ex.getSQLException().getSQLState()) &&                                  ex.getSQLException().getErrorCode() == 4068;        }

But is there more elegant way to overcome this problem, not really wanting to place this try-catch block in many DAO objects where the jdbcCall.execute(params) is used. Yes I can do a wrapper for SimpleJdbcCall with try-catch and inject this wrapper where it is needed but maybe there is a possibility to fine tune datasourse to really close connections or remove them completely once it is returned to connection pool? Or is there a the solution to create any query which can validate an oracle package state and use it in 'spring.datasource.validation-query' instead of 'select 1 from dual'.Thanks for your help in advance.P.S I'm using org.apache.tomcat.jdbc.pool.DataSource and oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver

By The way, code has an issue, so the method returns empty result.It is somehow connected to try-catch block.The first time when there is an error, the callProcedure(params) method triggers once again in catch block and returns result, but then I don't know why but result returns from the call which had been before catch block. And it is an empty map.

Here is my workable solution.1) Extend SimpleJdbcCall2) override execute method:

public class MyJdbcCall extends SimpleJdbcCall {    public MyyJdbcCall(DataSource dataSource) {        super(dataSource);    }    public Map<String, Object> execute(SqlParameterSource parameterSource) {        Map<String, Object> results = Collections.EMPTY_MAP;        try {            results = executeInternal(parameterSource);        } catch (UncategorizedSQLException ex) {            if (checkOra04067Exception(ex)) {                results = executeInternal(parameterSource);            }        }        return results;    }    private Map<String, Object> executeInternal(SqlParameterSource parameterSource) {        return super.execute(parameterSource);    }    private boolean checkOra04067Exception(UncategorizedSQLException ex) {        return SQL_STATE_72000.equals(ex.getSQLException().getSQLState())                && ex.getSQLException().getErrorCode() == SQL_ERROR_CODE_4068;    }}
Title: Oracle stored procedure recompilation and Sprig SimpleJdbcCall

Body:
I want to make a progress bar like Timberman game. This is my Java code:

boolean flagProgress=false;private void click() {// click 1 button    if(!flagProgress){        taskProgress=new TaskProgress();        AsyncTaskCompat.executeParallel(taskProgress,                500+10);     }    else {        taskProgress.cancel(true);        int progress=progressBar.getProgress();        taskProgress=new TaskProgress();        AsyncTaskCompat.executeParallel(taskProgress,                progress+10);    }}  class TaskProgress extends AsyncTask<Integer, Integer, Void> {    @Override    protected void onPostExecute(Void aVoid) {        super.onPostExecute(aVoid);        doGameOver();    }    @Override    protected void onPreExecute() {        super.onPreExecute();        flagProgress=true;    }    @Override    protected void onProgressUpdate(Integer... values) {        super.onProgressUpdate(values);        progressBar.setProgress(values[0]);                }    @Override    protected Void doInBackground(Integer... params) {        if(params[0]>1000)// max 1000            params[0]=1000;        setProgress(params[0]);        for(int i=params[0];i>=0;i--) {            if(isCancelled())                break;            publishProgress(i);            SystemClock.sleep(100);        }        return null;    }    @Override    protected void onCancelled() {        super.onCancelled();    }}

Everything went right(my Progress bar looked like Progress bar in Timberman game) until I played my game 20 times or more (game over and play again). My progress bar stopped and sometimes sound effect didn't play. Note: I also have an other AsyncTask so I use AsyncTaskCompat.executeParallel.Who can help me? :(.
Title: Asynctask go wrong when executing so many times

Body:
I am using two maven modules of a same project.One is to create a maven plugin, to get all the files with extension 'myextn' of a specified directory.

I am using org.apache.commons.io.FileUtils to get the files.

My sample code is here:

File specificationDirectory = new File(System.getProperty('user.dir')+File.separator+src'+File.separator+'test'+File.separator);String[] extension = new String[] { 'myextn' };List<File> files = (List<File>) FileUtils.listFiles(specificationDirectory, extension, true);

Another module have the directory and files, and uses the plugin.I am getting the desired result if the files and directory is available in the plugin module,I am not getting the result when I have the files in the second module, which uses the plugin. When I trying to run the second module, I am getting the following error , 'Parameter 'directory' is not a directory'

My objective is very simple, I have the files in a directory (secondProject/src/test) within the second module, I want to list down the files in this directory using the plugin which has the logic to do this.

Can anyone please help me to get this objective.
Title: Error in maven-plugin : 'Parameter 'directory' is not a directory'

Body:
Im being mad with a problem that is hard to resolve for me without your help. I'm creating a Tomcat's project with servlet/jstl/jsp technology and I have a problem uploding photos.

For example: a user update his profile image. He click on the submit button of the multipart form in the html and then a servlet will process his request. My servlet use multipart for uploading files. The servlet will update the image profile in the database with the new name of the photo (updating the user object in the session too) and, at the end, it will return a page where the profile image should be up to date, but it will not be loaded. If I inspect the img element, the path is right because if I copy the img source in the address-bar it will show the right image.

I suppose the problem is the following: the multipart request will process the upload the file asynchronous, so when the servlet redirect to the profile.jsp page, it will have trouble loading an image that is being written on disk at this moment. I suppose this is the problem, but I'm not sure.Is there a way to wait for multipart to finish loading the photo, because if I refresh the profile.jsp page, the photo is painted clearly on the screen without problems.

This is the code in the doPost method of the Servlet (semplified without null control, ...)

MultipartRequest multi = new MultipartRequest(request, manager.completePath + '/web' + dirName, 10 * 1024 * 1024, 'ISO-8859-1', new DefaultFileRenamePolicy());Enumeration files = multi.getFileNames();String name = null;while (files.hasMoreElements()) {    name = (String) files.nextElement();}RequestDispatcher rd;String newAvPath = multi.getFilesystemName(name);HttpSession session = request.getSession();User user = (User) session.getAttribute('user');user.updateImgProfile(newAvPath);rd = request.getRequestDispatcher('/profile.jsp');  rd.forward(request, response);

Excuse me in advance for my English because I'm Italian and thanks all :)
Title: Tomcat Servlet: Waiting to a file to be completely uploaded and saved on disk

I started creating a basic roleplaying game and I have a problem with the design. I have Character class that includes all the stats and info ( like name, character class, level, hit points, experience points etc.). I have an abstract class named CharacterClass that has some subclasses (like Fighter, Mage etc.). The abstract class CharacterClass has most info that Character has, but not all of it (it doesn't have experience points for instance). The problem is that I have a code duplication ( I create a character by creating a character class (like Fighter, and then assign the data to Character's construction, with some additions), both have strength, hit points, and getHitPoints, and setHitPoints for instance. How can I avoid this ?

Character          CharacterClass (abstract)                   Fighter  Mage  Rogue Cleric (all extend CharacterClass)

If it helps to understand, then when I create a character I have this code:

switch (choice){        case 'Fighter':            chosenClass = new Fighter();            break;        case 'Rogue':            chosenClass = new Rogue();            break;        case 'Mage':            chosenClass = new Mage();            break;        case 'Cleric':            chosenClass = new Cleric();            break;    }    try {        hero = new Character(name, chosenClass);
Title: Java RPG Object-oriented design

Body:
I am trying to look at memory management in Java. I have a program that creates a large collection (~500MB). I run java without any special arguments. Once this collection goes out of scope, I invoke the garbage collector using System.gc(). From jconsole, I can see that the heap memory in use is dramatically reduced. The same cannot be said of the RES output of the top linux command.

My only interpretation is that once the JVM gets hold of memory, it does not release it to the system as long as it is running. Is this correct?
Title: Reconciling outputs of jconsole and top

Body:
Handling multipart file uploads in Spring controllers works with either org.springframework.web.multipart.MultipartFile or Servlet 3.0's multipart parsing using javax.servlet.http.Part. Both of these classes have a method to write the uploaded file by simply moving it if it is already on disk like so:

public String uploadFile(@RequestParam('path') String path, @RequestParam('file') Part file) throws IOException {    Path dstPath = Paths.get('somePath', path);    // From write's javadoc:    /*     * A convenience method to write an uploaded part to disk. The client     * code is not concerned with whether or not the part is stored in     * memory, or on disk in a temporary location. They just want to write     * the uploaded part to a file.     *     * This method is not guaranteed to succeed if called more than once for     * the same part. This allows a particular implementation to use, for     * example, file renaming, where possible, rather than copying all of     * the underlying data, thus gaining a significant performance benefit.     */    file.write(dstPath.toString());    return 'response';}public String uploadFile(@RequestParam('path') String path, @RequestPart('file') MultipartFile file)        throws IOException {    Path dstPath = Paths.get('somePath', path);    // From transferTo's javadoc:    /*     * Transfer the received file to the given destination file. <p>This may     * either move the file in the filesystem, copy the file in the     * filesystem, or save memory-held contents to the destination file. If     * the destination file already exists, it will be deleted first. <p>If     * the file has been moved in the filesystem, this operation cannot be     * invoked again. Therefore, call this method just once to be able to     * work with any storage mechanism. <p><strong>Note:</strong> when using     * Servlet 3.0 multipart support you need to configure the location     * relative to which files will be copied as explained in {@link     * javax.servlet.http.Part#write}.     */    file.transferTo(dstPath.toFile());    return 'response';}

When an uploaded part is large enough, it is written to a temporary file to avoid using up too much memory. The 2 methods from the above examples avoid using streams to copy the file to the intended final destination which can be a big performance improvement for large files.

However, I can't figure out how to achieve the same thing when the uploaded file is sent as the 'raw' request body. Here is what I do now:

public String uploadFile(@RequestParam('path') String path, InputStream file) throws IOException {    // Spring maps the request body to the InputStream file    Path dstPath = Paths.get('somePath', path);    Files.copy(file, dstPath);    return 'response';}

Is there a way to avoid using streams to write the file to its destination? When uploading large files, the request is certainly already written to temporary disk storage to avoid running out of memory. Can this be leveraged somehow?
Title: How to avoid stream copy when uploading file as request body

Body:
I am using:spring-boot 1.0.2.RELEASEspring-security-ldap: 3.2.4.RELEASE

I am trying to authenticate users with our AD server. I do not want to load roles, this will be handled locally. Here is my security configuration:

@Overrideprotected void configure(AuthenticationManagerBuilder auth) throws Exception {    ActiveDirectoryLdapAuthenticationProvider provider = new ActiveDirectoryLdapAuthenticationProvider('<my-domain>', 'ldap://<my-server>:389');    provider.setConvertSubErrorCodesToExceptions(true);    provider.setUseAuthenticationRequestCredentials(true);    auth.authenticationProvider(provider);}

Inspecting in wireshark shows the following:

LDAP  bindRequest(1) '<user>@<my-domain>' simpleLDAP  bindResponse(1) successLDAP  searchRequest(2) 'dc=<my-domain>' wholesubtreeLDAP  searchResDone(2) referralLDAP unbindRequest(3)

I can see that the bind request is succeeding, it is the directory search that is failing (getting referred). As far as I am concerned, this is a success, and I do not care about the searchRequest. Is there any way to skip this step and perform only the bind?

I have tried a variety of things, all without success. Many solutions seem to be to specify a more accurate DN, or follow referals. I do not know what the DN should be, and cannot install any tools to discover this (if there are any other ways please let me know!). I have read that following referals can slow it down somewhat, I am wondering If I can simply skip this step and treat the authentication as successful

Thanks!
Title: Spring Security LDAP Authentication only: PartialResultsException

Body:
I've used Hessian for a while but just noticed the following behavior. If you serialize a java.lang.Character in Hessian, it deserializes as a String.

public class TestHessianChar {    public static void main(String... args) throws IOException {        // Serialize        Character c = new Character('x');        ByteArrayOutputStream byteArrayOutputStream = new ByteArrayOutputStream();        Hessian2Output hessian2Output = new Hessian2Output( byteArrayOutputStream );        hessian2Output.startMessage();        hessian2Output.writeObject(c);        hessian2Output.completeMessage();        hessian2Output.close();        byte[] dataBytes = byteArrayOutputStream.toByteArray();        // Deserialize        Hessian2Input hessian2Input = new Hessian2Input( new ByteArrayInputStream(  dataBytes ) );        hessian2Input.startMessage();        Object o = hessian2Input.readObject();        hessian2Input.completeMessage();        hessian2Input.close();        System.out.println(o.getClass().getName());    }}

Output for this code is:

java.lang.String

I'm assuming it has something to do with language-independent serialization of primitives, but it's rather annoying. I am writing a JMS driver and need to distinguish between char and String, since the spec demands different behavior. I'm considering writing my own class to represent a char (and give up auto-boxing), but I wanted to know if there is a proper way to get Hessian to treat a Character as a Character before I start going through such contortions.
Title: Hessian deserializes java.lang.Character as a String

Body:
I have a application which uploads spreadsheet from UI, where js file do the ajax call to the rest endpoint from UI. I need to do the validation once it reaches the server side like I need to check for empty cells, like if any empty cells are present in 4 specific columns at specific indexes 0,2,4,6 then the spreadsheet should be rejected (we were told Column names are dynamic so the only possibility we can check is through index positions). I am doing this by using java apache poi. I did validation check for checking empty cells like below which is working fine. //checking for empty cells at indexes 0,2,4,6

if((row.getCell(0) == null || row.getCell(0).getCellType() == Cell.CELL_TYPE_BLANK)  ||       (row.getCell(2) == null || row.getCell(2).getCellType() == Cell.CELL_TYPE_BLANK)  || (row.getCell(4) == null || row.getCell(4).getCellType() == Cell.CELL_TYPE_BLANK) ||          (row.getCell(6) == null || row.getCell(6).getCellType() == Cell.CELL_TYPE_BLANK) ||       {      result = true;           }

But the real problem is there will be different sheets in a single spreadsheet and each sheet has different number of columns, For Example some sheets may have 3 columns, some may have 5 columns for which the above validation fails, Like even though the column doesn’t exist the above logic returns true since it has empty cell. How can we tackle this? How do we check for column existence and then check for empty cells only if the column exists? Can anyone help me out on this.
Title: How to check for Column existence in Excel file using java apache Poi

Body:
My program is a dice rolling game. You run the program and it rolls two dice that randomly generate a number between one and six, adds them up, and then prompts the user if they want to roll again. When the user is prompted an user responds with 'y' then the code should return to the top and run again. Unfortunately it runs only once. How do I get the code to run again when the user types 'y'?

import java.util.Scanner;public class Chapter2 {static Scanner console = new Scanner(System.in);public static void main(String[] args){    String userInput = null;    do {        int rollOne = (int)(Math.random()*6)+1;        int rollTwo = (int)(Math.random()*6)+1;        System.out.println('Roll One equals '  + rollOne);        System.out.println('Roll Two equals ' + rollTwo);        System.out.println('Roll One + Roll Two equals ' + (rollOne + rollTwo));        System.out.println('Would you like to roll again?');        userInput = console.nextLine();    }while(userInput == 'y');}}

The action bar will        // automatically handle clicks on the Home/Up button, so long        // as you specify a parent activity in AndroidManifest.xml.        int id = item.getItemId();//        //noinspection SimplifiableIfStatement//        if (id == R.id.action_settings) {//            return true;//        }        return super.onOptionsItemSelected(item);    }    @Override    public void onDrawerItemSelected(View view, int position) {        displayView(position);    }    private void displayView(int position) {        Fragment fragment = null;        String title = getString(R.string.app_name);        switch (position) {            case 0:                fragment = new Transactionfragment();                title = getString(R.string.title_transaction);                break;            case 1:                fragment = new Settingsfragment();                title = getString(R.string.title_settings);                break;//            case 2://                fragment = new MessagesFragment();//                title = getString(R.string.title_messages);//                break;            default:                break;        }        if (fragment != null) {            FragmentManager fragmentManager = getSupportFragmentManager();            FragmentTransaction fragmentTransaction = fragmentManager.beginTransaction();            fragmentTransaction.replace(R.id.container_body, fragment);            fragmentTransaction.commit();            // set the toolbar title            getSupportActionBar().setTitle(title);        }    }}

Body:
Below code i use for a sms gateway.I'm Using smslib jar. The code is working perfectly. But i need to handle incoming and outgoing sms. some time the code has a bug. that is a exception coming when program running. I use a dongle as a modem. Some time take long time to receive sms. I think the issue is i never handle the service for receiving and sending sms.So how can i solve this?

public class receiver {SMSClient m = null;SerialModemGateway gateway;int last = -1;ArrayList<InboundMessage> msgList = null;public void initGateway() {    try {        if (gateway == null) {            ResultSet rss = DB.getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery('Select * From config where id=1 ');            if (rss.next()) {                String mod_port = 'modem.' + rss.getString(3);                gateway = new SerialModemGateway(mod_port, rss.getString(3), 115200, rss.getString(4), rss.getString(5));                gateway.setProtocol(Protocols.PDU);                gateway.setInbound(true);                gateway.setOutbound(true);                gateway.setSimPin(rss.getString(6));                gateway.setSmscNumber(rss.getString(2));                Service.getInstance().addGateway(gateway);                Service.getInstance().startService();            }        }        new Thread(new Runnable() {            @Override            public void run() {                run_server();            }        }).start();    } catch (Exception ex) {        JOptionPane.showMessageDialog(null, ex.toString(), 'Error', JOptionPane.INFORMATION_MESSAGE);    }}public void run_server() {    int last = -1;    while (true) {        try {            msgList = new ArrayList<InboundMessage>();            Service.getInstance().readMessages(msgList, InboundMessage.MessageClasses.ALL);            for (InboundMessage im : msgList) {                ResultSet rsl = DB.getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery('Select * From last where id='1'');                if (rsl.next()) {                    last = Integer.parseInt(rsl.getString(2));                }                if (last < im.getMemIndex()) {                    ResultSet rs = DB.getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery('Select * From codes where code='' + im.getText() + ''');                    if (rs.next()) {                        ResultSet rs2 = DB.getConnection().createStatement().executeQuery('Select * From sms_log where code='' + im.getText() + '' AND tel_no='' + im.getOriginator() + ''');                        if (rs2.next()) {                            gateway.sendMessage(new OutboundMessage(im.getOriginator(), 'The Code is Already Verified... Thank You!.'));                            System.out.println('The Code is Already Verified... Thank You!.');                        } else {                            Date dNow = new Date();                            SimpleDateFormat ft= new SimpleDateFormat('E yyyy-MM-dd 'at' hh:mm:ss a zzz');                            gateway.sendMessage(new OutboundMessage(im.getOriginator(), 'The Code Verified... Thank You!.'));                            System.out.println('The Code Verified... Thank You!.');                            DB.getConnection().createStatement().execute('INSERT INTO sms_log (tel_no,code,status,date) values('' + im.getOriginator() + '','' + im.getText() + '',1,'' +ft.format(dNow)+'')');                        }                    } else {                        gateway.sendMessage(new OutboundMessage(im.getOriginator(), 'Invalid Code... Thank You!.'));                        System.out.println('Invalid Code... Thank You!.');                    }                    int last2 = last + 1;                    DB.getConnection().createStatement().execute('UPDATE last SET last_id=' + last2 + ' where id=1');                }            }            Thread.sleep(5000);            System.out.println('start');        } catch (Exception ex) {            Logger.getLogger(receiver.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);        }    }}

}
Title: SMS receiving not working real time corectly

Body:
I have a little confused with the Netty codec, I know I need add some codes to the pipeline, but how should I arrange the encoder and decoders? Can anybody give a simple explanation of the rules of how to arrange the encoder and decoders in a pipeline?

the server side code:

protected static void run() throws Exception {    ServerBootstrap b = new ServerBootstrap();    b.group(bossGroup, workerGroup);    b.channel(NioServerSocketChannel.class);    b.childHandler(new ChannelInitializer<SocketChannel>() {        @Override        public void initChannel(SocketChannel ch) throws Exception {            ChannelPipeline pipeline = ch.pipeline();                           pipeline.addLast('decoder', new HttpRequestDecoder());            pipeline.addLast(new ProtobufVarint32FrameDecoder());            pipeline.addLast('bufd',new                             ProtobufDecoder(PbConditions.Conditions.getDefaultInstance()));            pipeline.addLast('servercodec',new HttpServerCodec());            pipeline.addLast('aggegator',new HttpObjectAggregator(Integer.MAX_VALUE));            pipeline.addLast(new MemcachedServiceHandler());            pipeline.addLast('',new ProtobufEncoder());            pipeline.addLast('responseencoder',new HttpResponseEncoder());            pipeline.addLast('clientcodec',new HttpClientCodec());        }    });    b.bind(IP, PORT).sync();}
Title: How should I arrange the codec handlers in Netty?

Body:
I am befuddled by Tasker's Java function interface vs actual Java code, as well as the code itself. I'm relearning Java and newly leaning Tasker, so I need some help.

The use case I'm trying to implement is relatively simple:

ENTRY -> Button 'Mute' is pressed -> test if music is playing -> if yes, pause music / if no, go to next step -> set media volume to 0 -> END

Clearly I need a variable to govern the if/else statement in Step 3.

This brings me to my Java problem. I'm using some code scraped from one website or another and specialized it in Tasker like this:

- Tasker Java Function - instantiate a new AudioManager object called manager. The tasker interface structure is this ->> - Return**: manager>> - Class or Object**: Context>> - Function**: getSystemService {AudioManager} (String)>> - Param {string}**: audio- Call method isMusicActive(), which returns the Tasker-formatted variable, %playing. The Tasker interface structure is this ->> - Return {string}**: %playing>> - Class or Object**: manager>> - Function**: isMusicActive {boolean} ()>> - Param**: null {isMusicActive}

Using this, Tasker successfully returns a boolean value to the variable %playing; however, the interface makes very little sense to me because it changes everytime I enter a new value. For example, after I close the task, test it, and go to fix the inevitable error, new fields have appeared in the Java function interface. It's as confusing as hell. Is there a good way to overcome this behavior?

Based on Tasker's oddities, I thought it might help if I could see the code the interface is writing. No luck, so now I'm writing based on memories from 10 years ago:

>> - Object manage CONTEXT.getSystemService(AudioManager());>> - Boolean %playing manage.isMusicActive ();

Does the above work, even if a bit inefficiently? I'm not concerned with tuning the code. I will be the 1 user of it. It doesn't need to scale.

Back to Tasker... It looks like, after much flailing around, I got the function to work. However, I cannot get Tasker to react to any boolean logic (if %playing matches/equals true, pause music app).

I tested %playing using a Tasker Flash action, which shows that %playing is correctly set by the Java functions (true if music is playing/false if it is not). Why the Tasker task won't react correctly has been maddening.

I've done some digging and found Tasker only supports variables in a string format, thus if %playing is returned as a primative Java boolean type, the value contained in %playing needs to be converted to a string before being returned to Tasker, I think. (In Tasker, I'm not even sure how to test a boolean variable but the Flash action seems able to read the variable - Maybe %playing is actually being returned as a string??)

If I had to modify the code to convert from a booleen value to a string, , would the following work?

>> - Boolean playing manager.isMusicActive ();>> - %playing = playing.toString ();

I'm sorry this post is so lengthy, but I didn't know how to break the problem into two or more posts, and I really want to beat this problem. Thanks for the help!
Title: Tasker Java Code Interface

int x = 0;int count = 0;String charector = '';while (charector != null) {    charector = inputLine.substring(x , x + 1);    if (charector == '/') {        count = count + 1;    }    if (count == 4) {        break;    }    System.out.println(charector);    x = x + 1;}

Body:
I have hibernate filter like this:

@Entity@FilterDef(name = 'filter_name', parameters = { @ParamDef(name = 'tenatId', type = 'long') })@Filter(name = 'filter_name', condition = 'tenant_id = :tenantId')public class MyEntity {   private long tenantId;}

And I want to enable this filter every time request come, so I create Request Interceptor like this:

@Configurationpublic class RequestInterceptor implements HandlerInterceptorAdapter {    @PersistenceContext    private EntityManager entityManager;    @Override    public boolean preHandle(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response,        Object handler) throws Exception {        Filter filter = entityManager.unwrap(Session.class).enableFilter('filter_name');        filter.setParameter('tenantId', myService.getTentantId());    }}

But I cannot the transaction manager, got error:

java.lang.IllegalStateException: No transactional EntityManager available    at org.springframework.orm.jpa.SharedEntityManagerCreator$SharedEntityManagerInvocationHandler.invoke(SharedEntityManagerCreator.java:272)    at com.sun.proxy.$Proxy184.unwrap(Unknown Source)    at id.gdplabs.koi.api.config.security.RequestInterceptor.preHandle(RequestInterceptor.java:27)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.handler.WebRequestHandlerInterceptorAdapter.preHandle(WebRequestHandlerInterceptorAdapter.java:56)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.HandlerExecutionChain.applyPreHandle(HandlerExecutionChain.java:134)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doDispatch(DispatcherServlet.java:958)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.DispatcherServlet.doService(DispatcherServlet.java:897)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.processRequest(FrameworkServlet.java:970)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.doGet(FrameworkServlet.java:861)    at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:622)    at org.springframework.web.servlet.FrameworkServlet.service(FrameworkServlet.java:846)    at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:729)    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.internalDoFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:230)    at org.apache.catalina.core.ApplicationFilterChain.doFilter(ApplicationFilterChain.java:165)    at org.apache.tomcat.websocket.server.WsFilter.doFilter(WsFilter.java:52)...

It works if I move the code to controller:

@RequestMapping(method = RequestMethod.GET, value = '/test')public List<MyEntity> test() {    Filter filter = entityManager.unwrap(Session.class).enableFilter('filter_name');    filter.setParameter('tenantId', myService.getTentantId());    return myService.findAll();}

Do you have idea why I cannot unwrap hibernate session in the Interceptor?

Any suggestion are welcome, Thanks!
Title: Enable hibernate filter on HandlerInterceptor

Body:
I am simulating an OSPF scenario where i have a file router.java that runs as multiple instance each instance acts as a single node. I then compute the shortest path between routers. After that, I need to transfer file from node 1 to node 4 in the following way:

node 1 --> node 2 --> node 3 --> node 4

Here initially when sending file from node 1 to node 2, node 1 acts as server and node 2 as client. Then when sending the file from node 2 to node 3, node 2 acts as a server and node 3 acts as a client. How do I achieve this over multiple nodes?

Mainly, how do I sync timing between nodes?
Title: Java - File transfer over multiple nodes

Body:
I am currently trying to make an application written from scratch to be deployable on a Tomcat 6.0.32 cluster, with session/state replication.

Everything works fine except for one thing: if one node of the cluster fails and a request is being redirected to another node, I am no longer logged in. After I log back in, the state of the Session and Conversation scoped beans is restored, so replication basically works except for the login part.

I have tried everything and I really ran out of ideas. Can someone please give me a hint ?

My configuration is as follows: Apache HTTPD and modjk, Apache Tomcat 6.0.32 ,Seam 2.2.2.Final

I have marked the application distributable in web.xml with:

<distributable />

In components.xml:

...<core:init debug='false' distributable='true' />...<security:identity authenticate-method='#{authenticator.authenticate}' />...

The authenticator class (basically you can login without user/pass at the moment):

@Name('authenticator')@Scope(ScopeType.EVENT)public class ResidentAuthenticator implements Serializable {private static final long serialVersionUID = 4655419361907742527L;    public boolean authenticate() {        return true;    }}

So, does anybody have an idea? Thanks !
Title: Seam Framework Clustering: Login state NOT replicating (Seam 2.2.2 + Tomcat 6.0.32)

I am new to Android Development. I implemented an option in my android app for switching between FULL SCREEN and Normal Screen. Below is my code to do that. But I have experience one problem. When I Switch my app to Full Screen mode, all SCROLL VIEWS on my activity stops scrolling. And when I switch back to normal screen all Scroll Views work fine. Help me.

//Shared Preferences    SharedPreferences screenPreference = getSharedPreferences('MyAppSettings', MODE_PRIVATE);    int ScreenFlag = screenPreference.getInt('ScreenFlag', 0);    SharedPreferences.Editor editor = screenPreference.edit();    switch(ScreenFlag)    {    case 0:     //set preference ScreenFlag, app running first time    case 2:     //Full screen - OFF        getWindow().addFlags(WindowManager.LayoutParams.FLAG_FORCE_NOT_FULLSCREEN);        getWindow().clearFlags(WindowManager.LayoutParams.FLAG_FULLSCREEN);        editor.putInt('ScreenFlag', 2);        editor.commit();        break;    case 1:     //Full screen - ONN        getWindow().addFlags(WindowManager.LayoutParams.FLAG_FULLSCREEN);        getWindow().clearFlags(WindowManager.LayoutParams.FLAG_FORCE_NOT_FULLSCREEN);        editor.putInt('ScreenFlag', 1);        editor.commit();        break;    default:        break;    }    setContentView(R.layout.activity_main);    //end - Shared Preferences
Title: Full Screen Android App feature

Body:
Recently I've been working on an application which would display notifications. I tryed to use NotificationListenerService class but when I call the getActiveNotifications() it returns null, even though there are active notifications. I checked if the service has the BIND_NOTIFICATION_LISTENER_SERVICE permission, and it does not have it, even though I ask for it in the manifest file. I have granted permission to the application at the Settings > Security > Access to notifications.
Here are my codes that I use:
Manifest:

<service android:name='.NLService'              android:permission='android.permission.BIND_NOTIFICATION_LISTENER_SERVICE'>            <intent-filter>         <action android:name='android.service.notification.NotificationListenerService' />     </intent-filter>        </service>

MainActivity where I call the service from:

startService(new Intent(LockScreenActivity.this, NLService.class));

And the NotificationListenerService class:

@Override    public int onStartCommand(Intent intent, int flags, int startId) {         String permission = 'android.permission.BIND_NOTIFICATION_LISTENER_SERVICE';            int res = this.checkCallingOrSelfPermission(permission);            boolean granted = (res == PackageManager.PERMISSION_GRANTED);  //this is false      final StatusBarNotification[] nots = this.getActiveNotifications(); // this is null        return super.onStartCommand(intent, flags, startId);    }

Thanks for any help in advance!
Title: NotificationListenerServic doesn't have the BIND_NOTIFICATION_LISTENER_SERVICE permission

Body:
I would like to annotate my request methods for the swagger maven plugin so that only the properties I actually need are displayed in the swagger request parameter schema, instead of all properties of a class. For example, if I have a person class with an email and a physical address, I only need to specify the physical address for sending normal mail and vice versa for emails, but the generated swagger shows both for both calls.

Example:

The example person class:

public class Person {    private String name;    private String email;    private String address;    /* getters / setters */}

The resource class I need to annotate:

@Api@RequestScoped@Path('odpiranjeRacuna')@Consumes(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)public class PersonResource {    @EJB    PersonSB personSB;    @ApiOperation(value='Send an email')    @POST    @Path('email')    public Response sendEmail(@ApiParam Person person){        return Response.ok().entity(personSB.sendMail(person.getEmail(), person.getName())).build();    }    @ApiOperation(value='Send a regular mail')    @POST    @Path('snailmail')    public Response sendSnailmail(@ApiParam Person person){        return Response.ok().entity(personSB.sendSnailmail(person.getAddress(), person.getName())).build();    }}

(Abbreviated) generated swagger:

{  'swagger' : '2.0',  'paths':{    '/email' : {      'post' : {        'summary' : 'Send an email',        'parameters' : [ {          'in' : 'body',          'name' : 'body',          'required' : false,          'schema' : {            '$ref' : '#/definitions/Person'          }        } ]      }    },    '/snailmail' : {      'post' : {        'summary' : 'Send a regular mail',        'parameters' : [ {          'in' : 'body',          'name' : 'body',          'required' : false,          'schema' : {            '$ref' : '#/definitions/Person'          }        } ]      }    }  },  'definitions':{    'Person' : {      'type' : 'object',      'properties' : {        'name' : {          'type' : 'string'        },        'email' : {          'type' : 'string'        },        'address' : {          'type' : 'string'        }      }    }  }}

(Abbreviated) desired swagger:

{  'swagger' : '2.0',  'paths':{    '/email' : {      'post' : {        'summary' : 'Send an email',        'parameters' : [ {          'in' : 'body',          'name' : 'body',          'required' : false,          'schema' : {            '$ref' : '#/definitions/PersonWithEmail'          }        } ]      }    },    '/snailmail' : {      'post' : {        'summary' : 'Send a regular mail',        'parameters' : [ {          'in' : 'body',          'name' : 'body',          'required' : false,          'schema' : {            '$ref' : '#/definitions/PersonWithAddress'          }        } ]      }    }  },  'definitions':{    'PersonWithEmail' : {      'type' : 'object',      'properties' : {        'name' : {          'type' : 'string'        },        'email' : {          'type' : 'string'        }      }    },    'PersonWithAddress' : {      'type' : 'object',      'properties' : {        'name' : {          'type' : 'string'        },        'address' : {          'type' : 'string'        }      }    }  }}

The difference being in request schema references and the schemas.
Title: Generating only the parameter properties I actually need with swagger-maven-plugin in Java

Body:
I'm using a customized animation for AlertDialog, for that I created the following file progress.xml

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?><animation-list android:id='@+id/anim_progress'   xmlns:android='http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android'>  <item android:drawable='@drawable/icon_progress_1'           android:duration='150'/>  <item android:drawable='@drawable/icon_progress_2'         android:duration='150'/>  <item android:drawable='@drawable/icon_progress_3'         android:duration='150'/>  <item android:drawable='@drawable/icon_progress_4'         android:duration='150'/>  <item android:drawable='@drawable/icon_progress_5'         android:duration='150'/> </animation-list>

This animation is used in a Layout progress general.xml

<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?><RelativeLayout xmlns:android='http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android'   ...    <ImageView        android:layout_width='85dp'        android:layout_height='85dp'        android:src='@anim/progress'        android:adjustViewBounds='true'/>  ...     </RelativeLayout>

Finally, I use this layout in a class that extends AlertDialog GeneralProgressDialog.java

public class GeneralProgressDialog extends AlertDialog{    public GeneralProgressDialog(Context context) {        super(context);    }    @Override    public void show() {        super.show();        setContentView(R.layout.progress_general);    }}

This code works in earlier versions of android, but does not work in android 5, the animation is static, please help. Thank you

Solved:

public void showProgress(){    dialog = new Dialog(this);    dialog.getWindow().requestFeature(Window.FEATURE_NO_TITLE);    dialog.getWindow().setBackgroundDrawable(new       ColorDrawable(Color.TRANSPARENT));    RelativeLayout contentView = (RelativeLayout)     ((Activity)this).getLayoutInflater().inflate(R.layout.progress_general,       null);    dialog.setContentView(contentView);    ImageView image =         (ImageView)contentView.findViewById(R.id.imgv_anim_progress);    final AnimationDrawable animation = (AnimationDrawable)         image.getDrawable();    dialog.setCancelable(false);    dialog.setOnShowListener(new OnShowListener() {        @Override        public void onShow(DialogInterface arg0) {            // TODO Auto-generated method stub            animation.start();        }    });    dialog.show();}

credits: Is it possible to have an animation-list in a dialog?
Title: AlertDialog with customized animation does not work on android 5

Body:
I need to handle requests that may have a number of sub path elements (that I can ignore), e.g. the following would all map to the same handler:

  • /abc?type=a
  • /abc/foo?type=a
  • /abc/foo/bar?type=a

The only code I have come up with is:

Handlers.pathTemplate().add('/{id}', handler).add('/{id}/foo', handler).add('/{id}/foo/bar', handler);

But this is not ideal as I need to define each possible path, is there anyway to allow (and ignore) any number of paths following my prefix e.g.

Handlers.pathTemplate().add('/{id}*', handler)

Handlers.path().addPrefixPath allows this sort of matching but then I would lose the path template variables.
Title: Anyway to have undertow path template with wildcards

Body:
Hello I am trying to implement restful web service using jersey. In which I want to set up connection to a remote database and do some DML operation. Here I am attaching my code. Please help me to create the client for it. I don't know how should I handle this VO at any client. I want to use this connection object to perform DML. DbConnectioVO is the simple VO containing only one variable Connection and it's getters and setters. Thanks in advanced. sorry for bad English. Please ask me fo rany further information if needed.

import java.sql.Connection;import java.sql.SQLException;import javax.ws.rs.Consumes;import javax.ws.rs.GET;import javax.ws.rs.PUT;import javax.ws.rs.Path;import javax.ws.rs.Produces; import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;import com.java.vo.DbConnectionVO;import oracle.jdbc.pool.OracleDataSource;@Path('/db')public class DbConnection {@Path('/conn')@PUT@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)@Consumes({MediaType.APPLICATION_XML,MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON})public DbConnectionVO dbConnect(DbConnectionVO dbVO) throws Exception{    try {        Connection conn=null;        String serverName = '12.36.25.21';        String protocol='tcp';        String sid='12';        int portNo=1111;        String userName='user';        String password='pwd';        OracleDataSource dataSource = null;        Class.forName('oracle.jdbc.OracleDriver');        dataSource = new OracleDataSource();        dataSource.setDriverType('thin'); // type of driver        dataSource.setServerName(serverName); // database server name        dataSource.setNetworkProtocol(protocol); // network protocol        dataSource.setDatabaseName(sid); // Oracle SID        dataSource.setPortNumber(portNo); // listener port number        dataSource.setUser(userName); // username        dataSource.setPassword(password); // password        conn = dataSource.getConnection();        conn.setAutoCommit(false);        dbVO.setConnection(conn);    } catch (SQLException e) {        throw e;    } catch (Exception e) {        throw e;    }    return dbVO;}}
Title: How to handle Jersey web services returning VO.?

I am upgrading my proj to spring 4.x from Spring 3.0. Accordingly, I have updated my beans.xml with new classes from the old classes(DefaultAnnotationHandlerMapping & AnnotationMethodHandlerAdapter). I assume, I am facing issues with the way I am handling RequestMappingHandlerMapping in spring 4.x

<code> <bean    class='org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerMapping'    p:interceptors-ref='threadSessionDataInterceptor' /><bean    class='org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerAdapter'>    <property name='messageConverters'>        <list>            <ref bean='stringMarshallingConverter'/>                                           <ref bean='jsonMarshallingConverter'/>                <ref bean='xmlMarshallingConverter'/>            <ref bean='xmlMarshallingConverter2'/>            </list>    </property> </bean> </code>

When I am starting the server after upgrading to spring 4.x, I am getting the following INFO messages in the stacktrace where it is throwing exception.

11:19:30,879 INFO [org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerMapping] (ServerService Thread Pool -- 48) Mapped '{[/sample/validateexample.json]}' onto public void com.fnservice.web.VerificatonController.addNotes(java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,java.lang.String,org.springframework.ui.Model) throws java.lang.Exception

11:19:30,915 INFO [org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.method.annotation.RequestMappingHandlerMapping] (ServerService Thread Pool -- 48) Mapped '{[/init/doInitialConfig.json],methods=[GET]}' onto public void com.fnservice.web.InitialConfController.doInitialConfig(org.springframework.ui.Model) throws java.lang.Exception

Below, I am mentioning the java code of VerificationController class for which server is throwing java.lang.Exception.

<code>@Controller@RequestMapping('/sample/*')public class AdVerificationController {private final static Log log =   LogFactory.getLog(AdVerificationController.class);@AutowiredAdVerificationService adVerificationService;@RequestMapping(value = 'validateexample.json')public void addNotes(@RequestParam(value = 'validateLane1', required = false)String Line1,        @RequestParam(value = 'validateLane2', required = false)String Line2,        @RequestParam(value = 'validateTe', required = false)String Te,         Model model)throws Exception {         {    AddXML add = new AddXML();    VerificationXML VerificationResponse = new AddVerificationXML();   ......... rest of code

But, when I run the same code with Spring 3.0, it is not throwing any exception. Please advice me as to whether I am doing anything wrong here.Below I am pasting the stacktrace when I run with Spring 3.0.

18:17:09,113 INFO [org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.annotation.DefaultAnnotationHandlerMapping] (ServerService Thread Pool -- 55) Mapped URL path [/address/validateExample.json] onto handler 'VerificationController'

18:17:09,129 INFO [org.springframework.web.servlet.mvc.annotation.DefaultAnnotationHandlerMapping] (ServerService Thread Pool -- 55) Mapped URL path [/init/doInitialConfig.json] onto handler 'initialConfController'
Title: issue with using Requestmappinghandlermapping in beans.xml spring 4.x

File file= new File('c:/xyz.bin');DataInputStream di= new DataInputStream(new FileInputStream(file));BufferedInputStream bin= new BufferedInputStream(dataIStream);byte[] byteArray= new byte[bin.available()];bin.read(byteArray);

And I am parsing the 'byteArray' according to my needs using my parserClass.Assigning the sub-bytes to different byte array members of the class 'someClass', and while printing Using custom Converter to convert byte array to String.

System.out.println('Name: '+Converter.String(        someClass.getFileName()));System.out.println('Num: '+someClass.getInteger());

Name: FILENAMENum: 2

String fileName= 'xyz.bin';InputStream in= getAssets().open(fileName);BufferedInputStream bin= new BufferedInputStream(new DataInputStream(in));byte[] byteArray= new byte[bin.available()];bin.read(byteArray);

public class SubMarine {

String SubName;Engine engS = new Engine();Missle SubMissle[] = new Missle[5];NavyMine SubMines[];public SubMarine(String subName, Engine engS, Missle[] subMissle,NavyMine[]SubMines) {    SubName = subName;    this.engS = engS;    SubMissle = subMissle;}public String getSubName() {    return SubName;}public void setSubName(String subName) {    SubName = subName;}public Engine getEngS() {    return engS;}public void setEngS(Engine engS) {    this.engS = engS;}public Missle[] getSubMissle() {    return SubMissle;}public void setSubMissle(Missle[] subMissle) {    SubMissle = subMissle;}public NavyMine[] getSubMines() {    return SubMines;}public void setSubMines(NavyMine[] subMines) {    SubMines = subMines;}public SubMarine() {    super();}public String toString() {    return 'SubMarine [SubName=' + SubName + ', engS=' + engS            + ', SubMissle='            + (SubMissle != null ? Arrays.asList(SubMissle) : null)            + ', SubMines='            + (SubMines != null ? Arrays.asList(SubMines) : null) + ']';}public SubMarine CheckWarHead(SubMarine s) {    int PowerM1 = 0, PowerM2 = 0;    for (int i = 0; i < this.getSubMissle().length; i++)    {        if (this.getSubMissle()[i] instanceof Torpedo) {            PowerM1+=((Torpedo)this.getSubMissle()[i]).getWarhead()                    .getOutput();        }        if (this.getSubMissle()[i] instanceof BalisticMissle)        {            for (int j = 0; j < ((BalisticMissle) this.getSubMissle()[i])                    .getWarBalistic().length; j++) {                PowerM1 += ((BalisticMissle) this.getSubMissle()[i])                        .getWarBalistic()[j].getOutput();            }        }    }    for (int i = 0; i < s.getSubMissle().length; i++)    {        if (this.getSubMissle()[i] instanceof Torpedo) {            PowerM2 += ((Torpedo) s.getSubMissle()[i]).getWarhead()                    .getOutput();        }        if (this.getSubMissle()[i] instanceof BalisticMissle)        {            for (int j = 0; j < ((BalisticMissle) s.getSubMissle()[i])                    .getWarBalistic().length; j++) {                PowerM2 += ((BalisticMissle) s.getSubMissle()[i])                        .getWarBalistic()[j].getOutput();            }        }    }    if(PowerM1>PowerM2)    return this ;    return s;}public boolean FireTorpedo(SubMarine Amarine) {    this.getSubMissle()[0].getEngine().setEngineStatus(true);// הפעלת מנוע                                                                // לפני ירי    this.getSubMissle()[0].setStatus(true);    this.getSubMines()[2].setMineStatus(true);    this.getSubMines()[3].setMineStatus(true);    int num = (int) (Math.random() * 2);    boolean EngineS = false;    boolean StatusMines = false;    if (num != 0)        EngineS = true;    num = (int) (Math.random() * 2);    if (num != 0)        StatusMines = true;    if (EngineS == true && StatusMines == false) {        System.out                .println('Torpedo hit  sumbarine coz the engine were on and didn't realse mines');        return true;    }    if (StatusMines == true) {        System.out.println('Torpedo Hit mines ');        return false;    }    return false;}

}i have problem with PowerM1 when it try to calculate SUM from class of arr its return me int and also have an error message NullPointerExeption,

any advices thanks
Title: JAVA Exception in thread 'main' java.lang.NullPointerException at SubMarine.CheckWarHead

I'm working on an android app that retrieves blog posts from a Blogger blog. I have included the following dependencies but I'm getting an 'cannot resolve symbol OAuth2Native'

Might I be missing an import or dependency?

These are the following dependencies I've included

compile 'com.google.apis:google-api-services-blogger:v3-rev53-1.22.0'compile 'com.google.api-client:google-api-client:1.22.0'compile 'com.google.apis:google-api-services-oauth2:v1-rev129-1.22.0'compile 'com.google.android.gms:play-services:10.0.1'

And these are the imports

import com.google.api.client.auth.oauth2.Credential;import com.google.api.client.auth.oauth2.*;import com.google.api.client.googleapis.auth.oauth2.GoogleAuthorizationCodeFlow;import com.google.api.client.googleapis.auth.oauth2.GoogleClientSecrets;import com.google.api.client.googleapis.javanet.GoogleNetHttpTransport;import com.google.api.client.http.HttpTransport;import com.google.api.client.http.javanet.NetHttpTransport;import com.google.api.client.json.Json;import com.google.api.client.auth.*;import com.google.api.client.json.JsonFactory;import com.google.api.client.json.jackson2.JacksonFactory;import com.google.api.services.blogger.Blogger;import com.google.api.services.blogger.BloggerScopes;import com.google.api.services.blogger.model.Post;

This is the code I'm trying to run from the Blogger Api website 

// The BlogId for the http://buzz.blogger.com/ blog.String BUZZ_BLOG_ID = '2399953';// The PostId for a buzz post with comments.String BUZZ_POST_ID = '5310628572012276714';// Configure the Java API Client for Installed Native AppHttpTransport HTTP_TRANSPORT = new NetHttpTransport();JsonFactory JSON_FACTORY = new JacksonFactory();// Configure the Installed App OAuth2 flow.Credential credential = OAuth2Native.authorize(HTTP_TRANSPORT,    JSON_FACTORY, new LocalServerReceiver(),    Arrays.asList(BloggerScopes.BLOGGER));// Construct the Blogger API access facade object.Blogger blogger = Blogger.builder(HTTP_TRANSPORT, JSON_FACTORY)    .setApplicationName('Blogger-PostsGet-Snippet/1.0')    .setHttpRequestInitializer(credential).build();// The request action.Get postsGetAction = blogger.posts().get(BUZZ_BLOG_ID, BUZZ_POST_ID);// Restrict the result content to just the data we need.postsGetAction.setFields('author/displayName,content,published,title,url');// This step sends the request to the server.Post post = postsGetAction.execute();// Now we can navigate the response.System.out.println('Title: ' + post.getTitle());System.out.println('Author: ' + post.getAuthor().getDisplayName());System.out.println('Published: ' + post.getPublished());System.out.println('URL: ' + post.getUrl());System.out.println('Content: ' + post.getContent());

Body:
I'm building a modular application with Spring and Spring Security. I had the security module working perfectly in the main architecture project but I've now decided to decouple them. In order to do so I tried 2 different approaches. Neither of them worked and I found there's very few documentation on these. I'd like to understand why with at last one of them.

Approach 1: web-fragments

In the first approach, I made another jar with a web-fragment. The web-fragment has only to register the Spring Security filter:

<!-- Spring security filter --><filter>    <filter-name>springSecurityFilterChain</filter-name>    <filter-class>org.springframework.web.filter.DelegatingFilterProxy</filter-class></filter><filter-mapping>    <filter-name>springSecurityFilterChain</filter-name>    <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern></filter-mapping>

Here Spring throws me an exception that says there's no bean named springSecurityFilterChain. I've read online that this may be caused by the security configuration being loaded later. So I've added the following lines to the web-fragment.xml:

 <!-- Loads the security fragment first --><ordering>    <before>        <others />    </before></ordering><listener><listener-class>    org.springframework.web.context.ContextLoaderListener</listener-class></listener><context-param>    <param-name>contextConfigLocation</param-name>    <param-value>/WEB-INF/security-context.xml</param-value></context-param>

I've also tried to explicitly define the bean in my security-context.xml and creating a java config class which only imports the security xml like this:

 @Configuration @EnableWebSecurity @ImportResource('classpath:WEB-INF/security-context.xml') public class SecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter{}

With this approach I got rid of the exception because the java config loaded the bean named springSecurityFilterChain. But it's not able to filter the servlet requests. At this point, I switched to the second approach.

Approach 2: Java config

I've decided to take advantage of the Spring component scanning that was already enabled on the main architecture. So, as the base package is the same, it should be able to get a bean annotated with @Configuration because it's implicitly annotated with @Component as the official Javadoc states. So I've converted my xml config file into a java one. For the sake of documentation I'll post them both. Again, I've found very little documentation on java config so I mostly did it myself and I'm aware that this may completely wrong:

security-context.xml

<!-- Entrypoints --><sec:http pattern='/rest/login' security='none' /><sec:http pattern='/rest/**' entry-point-ref='restAuthenticationEntryPoint'    create-session='stateless'>    <sec:csrf disabled='true' />    <sec:custom-filter before='FORM_LOGIN_FILTER' ref='jwtAuthenticationFilter' /></sec:http><!-- Enables @PreFilter, @PreAuthorize, @PostFilter, @PostAuthorize on any     Spring bean in context --><sec:global-method-security pre-post-annotations='enabled' /><!-- Beans --><beans:bean id='restAuthenticationEntryPoint'    class='co.aurasphere.aura.security.RestAuthenticationEntryPoint' /><beans:bean id='restSuccessHandler'    class='co.aurasphere.aura.security.RestAuthenticationSuccessHandler' /><beans:bean id='restFailureHandler'    class='org.springframework.security.web.authentication.SimpleUrlAuthenticationFailureHandler' /><beans:bean id='jwtAuthenticationProvider'    class='co.aurasphere.aura.security.JwtAuthenticationProvider'>    <beans:property name='jwtUtil' ref='jwtUtil' /></beans:bean><beans:bean id='jwtUtil' class='co.aurasphere.aura.security.JwtUtil' /><beans:bean id='jwtAuthenticationFilter'    class='co.aurasphere.aura.security.JwtAuthenticationFilter'>    <beans:property name='authenticationManager' ref='jwtAuthenticationManager' />    <beans:property name='authenticationSuccessHandler'        ref='restSuccessHandler' /></beans:bean><!-- Authentication managers --><sec:authentication-manager alias='jwtAuthenticationManager'>    <sec:authentication-provider ref='jwtAuthenticationProvider' /></sec:authentication-manager>

SecurityConfig.java

@Configuration@EnableWebSecurity@ImportResource('classpath:WEB-INF/security-context.xml')public class SecurityConfig extends WebSecurityConfigurerAdapter{@Autowiredprivate RestAuthenticationEntryPoint restAuthenticationEntryPoint;@Autowiredprivate RestAuthenticationSuccessHandler restAuthenticationSuccessHandler;@Autowiredprivate JwtAuthenticationFilter jwtAuthenticationFilter;@Autowiredprivate JwtAuthenticationProvider jwtAuthenticationProvider; @Override    protected void configure(AuthenticationManagerBuilder auth) throws Exception {        auth.authenticationProvider(jwtAuthenticationProvider); }    @Override    protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {         http        .csrf().disable()        .exceptionHandling()        .authenticationEntryPoint(restAuthenticationEntryPoint)        .and()          .authorizeRequests()        .antMatchers('/rest/**').authenticated()        .and()        .addFilter(jwtAuthenticationFilter);        http.antMatcher('/rest/login').securityContext().disable();            }    @Bean    public RestAuthenticationSuccessHandler mySuccessHandler(){        return new RestAuthenticationSuccessHandler();    }    @Bean    public SimpleUrlAuthenticationFailureHandler myFailureHandler(){        return new SimpleUrlAuthenticationFailureHandler();    }    @Override    protected AuthenticationManager authenticationManager() throws Exception {        return super.authenticationManager();    }

This throws me an IllegalArgumentException because the authenticationManager is null, even if I override the authenticationManager() method as I've read on SO. At this point I don't know anymore how to solve this, since I'm very unfamiliar with Spring Security Java config and I don't find any documentation on this topic. So I've decided to post this question. I don't mind switching back with the all-in-one module solution if I don't find another solution or get these to work, but I'd really like how this should be done properly, so I can improve my skills.

Any help is appreciated. Thank you very much!
Title: Decoupling Spring Security from Spring application

If the media type is APPLICATION_OCTET_STREAM and the response is a javax.ws.rs.core.StreamingOutput, swagger generates its own StreamingOutput model which is just a dummy object apparently useless to do anything.

This is the part of swagger spec which captures the info.

'get': {    'vendorExtensions': {},    'operationId': 'downloadResults',    'produces': [        'application/octet-stream'    ],    'parameters': [],    'responses': {        '200': {            'description': 'successful operation',            'schema': {                'type': 'ref',                'required': false,                'vendorExtensions': {},                '$ref': '#/definitions/StreamingOutput',                'refFormat': 'INTERNAL',                'simpleRef': 'StreamingOutput'            },            'headers': {},            'vendorExtensions': {}         }     } }

Is it possible to get an InputStream at the client side in the generated code?.
Title: swagger code gen : Handling StreamingOutput/Media type APPLICATION_OCTET_STREAM

Body:
I am using Jackson's Hibernate4Module to deal with the serialization issues when dealing with a lazily loaded proxy in a Spring Data Rest project.

In general it solves the issue of Jackson trying to serialise uninitialized proxies however one side effect is that the JSON output differs:

Fetched directly: api/cases/5400

{   'id': 5400,   'practiceReference': 'DWPYI9'}

Fetched via a lazily loaded @ManyToOne: api/submissions/11901/parentCase

{   'content': {      'id': 5400,      'practiceReference': 'DWPYI9'   }}

Fetched via a non-lazily loaded @ManyToOne: api/submissions/11901/parentCase

{   'id': 5400,   'practiceReference': 'DWPYI9'}

As can be seen in the above, the JSON representation differs when serializing a lazy @ManyToOne association: the entity is wrapped in the 'content' node.

If the association is non-Lazy then the same representation is written regardless of the path.

Is there a reason for this and can the additional 'content' node somehow be prevented?

Update

I have found the same (deleted) question here:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33194554/two-different-resulting-jsons-when-serializing-lazy-objects-and-simple-objects

which is referenced from:

https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-datatype-hibernate/issues/77

Also reported here so seems like a known issue:

https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-datatype-hibernate/issues/97
Title: Issue Serializing Lazy @ManyToOne
